title: Ticket #2152: Introduce multiple concurrent claim activations
description:
Motivation

Condor needs a way to deal with multiple concurrent claim activations: as things currently stand, we are able to have one Shadow/Starter per claim at a given time. Being able to support more concurrent Shadow/Starter pairs per claim would allow for streamlining input/output transfers, overlapping I/O and execution (see sandbox manager project), or even to run multiple, low-resource jobs at once. Various changes in Startd and Schedd are needed in order to accomodate this.

Involved objects

Match

A match is created by the negotiator between a user's job and a Startd's resource ("slot"). The negotiator informs both the startd and the schedd about the match. In Condor's current startd implementation, the match is manifested as a state ("matched state") in a resource's claim object. The lifetime of a match ends with the expiration of a claim (if a claim takes place), or times out. The scope of this work will not actually affect or modify the matching protocols or data structures.

Claim

A claim represents a provisioned resource. When a schedd is notified about a match, it typically proceeds to claim the resource. A claim object is maintained by the Schedd and the Startd. It contains information including the claim ID that was generated by the startd and passed to the schedd via the negotiator, and claim lease - a claim expires after a period of time if the lease is not renewed. A startd slot enters the Claimed/Idle state/activity upon being completion of the claiming protocol between the schedd and the startd.

Claim activation

 Once a match has been made and a resource is marked as claimed (aka provisioned), the claim is activated to indicate the instantiation of an activity on the resource. The claim activation protocol is typically initiated by the shadow contacting the startd; upon completion the startd slot is said to be Claimed/Active and the startd spawns a starter to manage the activation. Deactivation of a claim places the startd slot back into Claimed/Idle state. A Startd can still reject the activation if circumstances changed. This would lead to the Schedd relinquishing the claim. In order to make claim activation more explicit (and to allow multiple activations per claim), we propose to implement an activation object containing an activation ID, which will be scoped within a claim ID. An activation without a claim is meaningless. A more detailed description of what is needed within an explicit activation object can be found in the "design" part of this document.

Current claim activation protocol

The Startd side maintains interleaved claim and resource objects. Each claim object contains a Starter object if the claim is activated. The schedd side maintains a match record for each claim, managing information such as the current state of the claim, a shadow record if the claim is active containing information about a spawned shadow, a copy of the resource ad as sent from the negotiator at match time, address of a matched startd, and a claim id. Relevant for this work is what happens after a resource has been claimed by the Schedd; in other words, we do not propose any changes to the code that manages matching or claiming.

Given that the schedd already has a claimed resource and has identified a job it wants to launch on the resource, an the schedd initiates activation as follows:

  1. Schedd spawns a Shadow, and passes to the shadow a copy of the job ad augmented with some additional attributes that includes the startd address and the claim ID.
  2. Shadow sends a claim activate command to Startd, passing to the startd the claim ID and a copy of the job classad.
  3. The startd re-evaluates its policy expressions within the context of the job classad from the shadow and an updated machine ad; if policy decides the resource is no longer available, the Startd rejects the activation request, the Shadow shuts down, and Schedd relinquishes the claim.
  4. If Startd is will to activate the claim, it forks off a Starter to run the job, and passes the tcp socket initiated by the shadow to the starter. Thus the starter is born with a tcp socket connected back to the shadow.
  5. Once the jobs's execution and output data transfer are completed, the Starter sends the final update to the Shadow. The shadow then updates the final information in the job queue, and sends a deactivate command to the startd, resulting in the startd telling the starter to shutdown.
  6. While the job is running, the starter is sending update classads containing run-time information to both the shadow (for job policy enforcement) and the startd (so machine policy can refer to updated job attributes such as ImageSize).
  7. Starter exit triggers the Startd to change claim/resource state into CLAIMED/IDLE
  8. Shadow exit triggers match record update in Schedd
  9. Schedd tries to find next matching job for claim and spawns the next Shadow (which leads to the next activation)
  10. If no new job for claim can be found, the schedd tells the startd that the claim is relinquished, match record in Schedd deleted, and claim object in Startd destroyed.

Proposed Design

In this section we describe the proposed design changes in Startd and Schedd with associated objects to facilitate concurrent claim activations. The overall high-level change is the introduction of an explicit activation object, scoped and owned by the claim object. As before, there will be one shadow/starter instance pair per activation - but now a single claim may have X simultaneous shadow/starter pairs.

With regards to startd policy, all policy expressions will continue to operate at the claim level, not at the individual activation level. However, we propose one circuit breaker startd enforced limit on the number of activations allowed per claim as a property that can be set per slot.

Activation object

The activation object needs to contain a unique ID (only needs to be unique within claim) and a field for a Starter sinful string, which is currently maintained by the claim object. We propose the activation ID will be the current public-part of the claim ID with an additional field appended - this will minimize code disruption and assist in backwards compatibility.

Changes to the Startd

While in state CLAIMED/RUNNING, the Startd must be able to accept further activations on a claim.

  • In the startd, a Resource Claim object contains a Starter object and is responsible for activating a claim, managing a condor_starter, etc. Therefore, the Claim object needs to maintain a set of Activation objects. When a shadow is spawned, the schedd will generate an activation ID and pass it along to the shadow in the same manner as the claim ID. Requests from the shadow to the startd for activation (job launch) and deactivation (e.g. job held, removed, completed) need to include an activation ID, such that the appropriate Starter can be addressed. Activation does not necessarily imply spawning of a Starter but can and in the common case will.
  • The activation object therefore maintains the activation ID and a Starter sinful string (may be NULL)
  • Functions that address Starter object (such as Claim::setStarter or Claim::spawnStarter) will need to accept the activation ID as an additional argument - should default to 0 for backwards compatibility
  • It may make sense to introduce a new startd RPC to deactivate all activations associated with a claim: this would be an iteration over all activations.
  • Note that the process of vacating, suspending, continuing jobs would become an iteration over all activations, as startd policy expression always operate at the claim level.
  • Starters advertise information back to both the shadow and the Startd. For update ads sent back to the startd, it will be the Startd's responsibility to aggregate that information across all starters associated with the same claim. Optionally, we may consider the startd advertising non-aggregated activation-specific information as well, perhaps by leveraging nested classads.
  • Open issue: startd job hooks... we should allow job hooks to have multiple activations, but in terms of development milestones, we hope to postpone exposure of multi-activations to job hooks as future work. Part of our concern is we do not want to perturb the existing job hook API, as changing the API could cause hardship for clients.

Advantage: Starter remains unchanged, no new object is introduced

Disadvantage: Claim object needs to be extended by a list of activation objects, Startd behavior on claim activation/deactivation needs to be adjusted

Other possible approaches and motivation for chosen design

1) Modify the startd to support an array of starters. In this case, the starter changes very little if at all, and the startd changes only to support managing and signalling multiple starters. There is exactly one activation per starter, but potentially multiple starters per claim.

2) Modify the starter to support an array of activations. Here, there would be one starter per claim, and it would track the activations internally. There already exists this concept in the starter, but none of the existing code uses it.

3) Introduce a new daemon between the startd and starter(s) that manages the activations for a given claim. Here there would again be one starter per activation, all under the new daemon which represents a claim to the startd. This daemon would manage and the starters.

in all options, changes are needed to the startd (or more specifically, the Claim object) to accomodate multiple activations, reconnect, signalling all and/or specific activations, and combining the resources used into one set of resources so that policy enforcement can be applied at the claim level.

in option 2, more changes are needed to the starter in addition to the above, and in option 3 an entirely new daemon would be created. given that, it seems that option 1 requires changing fewer components in the condor system as a whole and leaves the starter largely untouched.
